issue.title: Wind plugin moved to world plugin

content.raw:
I agree that the current implementation is not optimal, but going to a world plugin model may be a fairly large revision.

For the wave forces, I’m currently working on synchronizing the visual and physical wave models - see this [work in progress wiki](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/Wave%20Field%20Generation).  The code is the wave\_visualization branch. .  Also, note that the way we handle wave forces on object primitives \(sphere, cylinder, etc.\) is different that the way we handle wave forces on the WAM-V.  Will have to think how we can unify that.   I’d like to get this branch merged before we consider refactoring the model/world plugin models for waves.

The wind plugin might be an easier place to start.  The current way empirical coefficient based model is briefly described in our documentation: [https://github.com/bsb808/robotx\_docs/blob/master/theoryofoperation/theory\_of\_operation.pdf](https://github.com/bsb808/robotx_docs/blob/master/theoryofoperation/theory_of_operation.pdf)  We’d need to be able to supply the coefficients for each model affected by the wind.  Also, currently the wind at different locations is completely independent.  With a world plugin we’d would really need a wind model that included spatial dimensions.

For the wave forces, I’m currently working on synchronizing the visual and physical wave models - see this work in progress wiki. The code is the wave_visualization branch. . Also, note that the way we handle wave forces on object primitives (sphere, cylinder, etc.) is different that the way we handle wave forces on the WAM-V. Will have to think how we can unify that. I’d like to get this branch merged before we consider refactoring the model/world plugin models for waves.

The wind plugin might be an easier place to start. The current way empirical coefficient based model is briefly described in our documentation: https://github.com/bsb808/robotx_docs/blob/master/theoryofoperation/theory_of_operation.pdf We’d need to be able to supply the coefficients for each model affected by the wind.
